exercises.setup_notes: Position the cable at a low setting and use a bar attachment. Stand facing away from the cable machine with arms overhead.
exercises.execution_notes: Bend and extend the elbows while keeping the arms overhead. Ensure the cable provides tension throughout the range of motion.
exercises.tier_reasons: Provides high tension in the stretched position, feels good, and allows for simple progression. Validated by a 2023 study showing 40% more triceps growth than press downs.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Long head, due to the overhead position providing a deep stretch.
exercises.scientific_insights: 2023 study found overhead extensions caused about 40% more triceps growth than press downs.
exercises.selection_reason: This exercise is selected as an S-Tier exercise for triceps, specifically targeting the long head due to the overhead position.  It provides high tension in the stretched position, feels good, and allows for simple progression, aligning perfectly with beginner needs and time constraints. The 2023 study supporting its effectiveness further strengthens its selection.

exercises.setup_notes: Use a barbell, grip slightly narrower than shoulder-width.
exercises.execution_notes: Lower the bar to the chest, press back up.
exercises.tier_reasons: Great for overload, consistent tension, but long head not fully engaged.
exercises.targeted_muscle_parts: Medial and lateral heads, due to pressing motion.
exercises.selection_reason: This A-Tier exercise is chosen to complement the Overhead Cable Triceps Extension by targeting the medial and lateral heads of the triceps.  Its suitability for beginners and its ability to allow for progressive overload make it a valuable addition to the workout. The alternative exercise, Bar Press Down, is also an A-Tier option but may not provide the same level of triceps engagement.

exercises.execution_notes: Ensure a deep stretch on the pecs with high tension throughout the range of motion. Maintain a stable position to enhance mind-muscle connection.
exercises.tier_reasons: Provides a deep stretch with high tension, smooth resistance profile, easy to overload, safer to push to failure.
exercises.additional_notes: Find a machine that feels good at your gym for optimal results.
exercises.selection_reason: Selected as an S-Tier chest exercise, the Machine Chest Press offers a deep stretch with high tension, a smooth resistance profile, and easy progressive overload, all crucial for beginners.  The machine's stability enhances mind-muscle connection, minimizing the risk of injury. The alternative, Bench Press, is also a good option but may be less comfortable for beginners.

exercises.execution_notes: Perform similar to flat dumbbell press but with an incline.
exercises.tier_reasons: Same benefits as flat dumbbell press with added upper pec emphasis.
exercises.selection_reason: This A-Tier exercise targets the upper pectorals, providing variety and ensuring balanced chest development. The incline variation allows for a good stretch and progressive overload, suitable for beginners. The alternative, Seated Cable Pec Fly, is also a good option but might be less accessible to beginners.

exercises.execution_notes: Press the weight overhead, keeping your core engaged and elbows slightly bent.
exercises.selection_reason: This exercise is a fundamental compound movement for shoulder development, engaging multiple muscle groups simultaneously. It's suitable for beginners and allows for progressive overload.

warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Extend arms to the sides and make small circles forward for 30 seconds, then backward for 30 seconds.
Roll shoulders forward in a circular motion for 30 seconds, then backward for 30 seconds.
Slowly straighten your arms and lift them until you feel a stretch in your chest. Hold for 15 seconds.
Bend your elbow and gently pull your elbow toward your head with your other hand. Hold for 15 seconds. Repeat on the other side.

warmup_exercises.setup_notes: Stand with feet together, arms at your sides.
warmup_exercises.execution_notes: Jump, spreading your legs and raising your arms overhead. Return to starting position. Perform for 1 minute.
